an8.24:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine.
an8.24:4.2: Then the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī, escorted by five hundred lay followers, went up to the Buddha,
an8.24:4.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an8.24:4.6: How do you bring together such a large following?”
an8.24:4.7: “Sir, I bring together such a large following by using the four ways of being inclusive as taught by the Buddha.
an8.24:4.8: When I know that a person
an8.24:4.9: can be included by a gift, I include them by giving a gift.
an8.24:4.10: When I know that a person
an8.24:4.11: can be included by kind speech, I include them by kind speech.
an8.24:4.12: When I know that a person
an8.24:4.13: can be included by taking care of them, I include them by caring for them.
an8.24:4.14: When I know that a person
an8.24:4.15: can be included by equality, I include them by treating them equally.
an8.24:4.16: But also, sir, my family is wealthy.
an8.24:4.17: They wouldn’t think that a poor person was worth listening to in the same way.”
an8.24:4.19: This is the right way to bring together a large following.
an8.24:4.20: Whether in the past, future, or present, all those who have brought together a large following have done so by using these four ways of being inclusive.”
an8.24:5.1: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Hatthaka of Āḷavī with a Dharma talk, after which he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.
an8.24:5.2: Then, not long after Hatthaka had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an8.24:5.3: “Mendicants, you should remember the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī as someone who has eight amazing and incredible qualities.
an8.24:5.13: You should remember the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī as someone who has these eight amazing and incredible qualities.”
